Award.AwardTitle: IGERT:REsponding to RApid Environmental CHange (REACH): From genes to ecosystems, science to society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: While shifting global climate and concomitant biological responses have always been part of Earth's history, the rapidity of current human-mediated environmental change is unprecedented. The most important of such changes include global warming, habitat loss and the introduction of species to novel geographic areas. Biologically, species may respond to rapidly changing environments through altered morphology, behavior or physiology. Humans uniquely adapt to environmental change by learning from the past, forecasting the future, and by using public policies to shape behavior. The goal of this Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) renewal award is to develop a multidisciplinary understanding of the biological and social mechanisms needed to respond to rapid environmental change. The dynamism of environmental problems means that solutions must be on-going accomplishments, requiring continuing commitment to monitoring, management, and adaptation. Graduate students, trained through coursework, research collaborations, and internships, will become proficient in the fundamental scientific and social issues involved in responding to rapid environmental change. Students will also organize workshops that bring together citizens, agency representatives, policymakers, non-governmental organizations and industry. New collaborations with Howard University and California State University-Fullerton will expand efforts to broaden participation. Because environmental change is global in scope, students will have opportunities to develop international collaborations through internships and research activities. All of the activities of the past and proposed IGERT make direct contributions to solving society's most pressing environmental problems. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the REACH IGERT, we developed graduate students’ multidisciplinary understanding of of how natural and human systems respond to rapid environmental change. Through an interdisciplinary cohort project and a non-academic internship, students learned to collaborate across disciplines, work with stakeholder groups with diverse views of an environmental problem, and its solutions. They also learned to communicate with the public through media-training and through student-organized workshops focused on the environmental problem addressed in the collaborative project.

The 2008 cohort studied the effect of reductions in funding for California’s Williamson Act. This program reduces property taxes of owners of 15 million acres of California rangeland, enables local governments and private landowners to restrict land parcels to agricultural use, and preserves the land for biological conservation. However, California budget cuts greatly reduced funding for this program.

Our trainees used geospatial analysis and a survey of 700 ranchers to assess the potential impact of loss of Williamson Act funds on ranchers and implications for conservation. Their analysis revealed that 72% of land in the Williamson Act contained habitat important for conservation goals. When asked their plans under a hypothetical elimination scenario, survey respondents reported intent to sell 20% of their total 496,889 acres. Further, 76% of the ranchers who reported that they would sell land predicted to be developed for non-agricultural uses, suggesting substantial changes to California’s landscape.

Our 2009 cohort examined how people in the US perceive fragranced personal care products as a case study of consumer behavior, how people obtain and perceive information, and factors that predict support for policy instruments to regulate use of fragrance chemicals in personal care products. Fragrance chemicals in personal care product remain unregulated in the US, even though some have documented environmental and health impacts.

The students found that 1400 survey respondents expressed moderate concern about environmental issues. Twenty-five percent reported seeking information about fragrances in personal care products, with 68% reporting that they read product labels. Only 23% knew that the government does not require labeling of fragrance chemicals in personal care products. Our students concluded that consumers need accessible information that details both health and environmental consequences and recommended policy regulations on product labeling, and incentives for industry transparency.

Floodplains have long been favored as sites for agriculture and settlement due to their fertility, flat topography, and proximity to rivers for easy transport of goods. They also provide ecosystem services and important habitat. Levees built to reduce flood risk have greatly reduced the ecological benefits that intact river-floodplain systems provide. Water managers now recognize that reconnecting floodplains can restore some ecological benefits while further reducing flood risk. However, few of these projects have been implemented because of the difficulty in estimating benefits and poor understanding of social conditions likely to affect project success.

Trainees from our 2010 cohort studied the consequences of river control projects along the Napa River. They found that much of the benefit went to businesses established in the formerly flood-prone downtown, while housing became scarcer for many low-income residents displaced by flood control. They also combined a hydraulic model with demographic models to examine how changes in flooding patterns might affect important fish and tree species.
